subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text:
* There are two Unicode z-variants, at code points U+585A and U+FA10. The latter form (U+FA10) has the next to last stroke of {{l|mul|豖}} connected to the top horizontal stroke (similar to {{l|mul|衣}}).
* The Japanese form of the character is written with {{l|mul|豕}} instead of {{l|mul|豖}} as its bottom right component. However both {{lang|ja|塚}} (Japanese) and {{lang|und|sc=Hant|塚}} (traditional Chinese) forms are encoded under the same codepoint.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: The [[Kangxi]] dictionary lists 塚 as the [[unorthodox]] form ([[俗字]]) of [[冢]]. However, the usage of 塚 persists in Japan with one stroke removed. In traditional and simplified Chinese [[冢]] is the [[orthodox]] form ([[正字]]) of the character. As a variant character, 塚 is used in mainland China.

subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|土|t1=earth|冢|ls=psc|c1=s|c2=p}} – an earthen mound, a tomb of earth.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}} {{wikipedia|Mound}}
{{ja-kanjitab|つか|yomi=k}} Cognate with {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=つか}} verb {{m|ja|築く|tr=tsuku||to build up using earth and/or stone}}.{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}} The {{IPAchar|/a/}} ending may indicate that ''tsuka'' developed as the [[nominalization]] of the {{m|ja|未然形|tr=mizenkei||[[irrealis]] form}} of the verb, suggesting an original meaning of "that which is being built up into an [[earthworks]] (but isn't finished yet)". The irrealis is also the root form for constructing the passive form of all Japanese verbs, so the original meaning might instead have been just the passive sense of "that which is built up into an earthworks".
